title: Russia’s Hooligan Army: Thugs threaten 'war' with England fans at World Cup 2018 - Mirror Online
text:

With their faces ominously hidden behind sinister masks, these are the “special forces” Russian hooligans who ran riot during Euro 2016 . 
And now the Orel Butchers are preparing for a mass assault on England fans in Moscow at next year’s World Cup . 
The football gang, or firm, spend hours in the gym and travel to fight clubs in remote forests to hone their combat skills. 
One gang member says: “Everyone is looking forward to the World Cup. For some it will be a festival of football, for others it will be a festival of violence. 
“Our opponents are the English, the forefathers of hooliganism. We are awaiting them. If you are there you should calculate getting your a*** kicked.” Read More This World: Russia's Hooligan Army talks to the Orel Butchers, supporters of Orel, a team in the 3rd division of Russian football (Photo: BBC) The gang members are looking forward to the World Cup as a 'festival of violence' (Photo: BBC) The yobs in action (Photo: BBC) 
At the Euros last June, dozens of England fans were injured, some nearly fatally, after being ambushed by squads of Russian thugs in military-style attacks in Marseilles, France, the day the two sides played . The violence prompted an inquiry into the threat posed by gangs at the World Cup in Russia. 
Speaking on the BBC2 documentary, Russia’s Hooligan Army, which airs tonight, the ringleader of the Orel Butchers, a semi-professional martial arts fighter called Denis, hides behind a balaclava as he boasts of his attacks. Violence between rival fans in the stands during the Euros (Photo: PA) One of Russia's Hooligan Army (Photo: BBC) One of the hooligans on the documentary (Photo: BBC) 
He says: “We were determined to mess up the British guys. It was like 200 professionals fighting 2,000 amateurs. 
“I hit a guy in the head. There was a British guy in a coma. I was thinking, ‘I bet that’s my guy because I really hit him properly’.” Spartak Moscow fans inside the stadium during the derby against CSKA Moscow (Photo: BBC) 
Unlike the lager louts who give England fans a bad name, these Russian hooligans are sober, muscular, and well drilled. The night before a fight they gather at a sauna to bond and feast on freshly caught crayfish to ensure they are in peak physical and mental condition the next day. 
One said: “I don’t see anything bad in this. Some collect stamps, some like mountain hiking, some collect cars. We fight. I think it is better than drinking alcohol, smoking, or taking drugs.” 
These gangs are also auditioning new members ready for the World Cup, taking them deep into the forest to fight hooligans from rival firms to prove themselves. The gangs keep themselves in peak condition for fighting Hooligan Army in training (Photo: BBC) The gang of hooligans (Photo: BBC) 
In one fight two gangs pitch 14 new recruits against each other to see who is tough enough. The victors earn a place in the firm and the right to have their tattoo emblazoned on their skin. 
There is only one rule. “Do not kill, that’s it,” one of the organisers explained. 
The violence is sickening. When one rookie is knocked to the ground a rival repeatedly stamps on his skull as he desperately tries to protect his head. It is a miracle no-one is seriously hurt. Footage from inside a stadium (Photo: BBC) This World: Russia's Hooligan Army (Photo: BBC) On the rampage (Photo: BBC) 
These forest fights are not just for new recruits. Gang veterans see them as fun and travel for miles to take part in clashes involving up to 200 hooligans, often in frozen fields knee-deep in snow. 
Their aim is clear. “Why do we fight the English? We are seeking pride,” says Denis. 
“There was a time people thought of Russians as vodka, folk guitar and furry boots. That has gone now. I like the fact I am Russian and people think we are the tough guys.” Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
